description: From Middle French postillon, and its likely source, Italian postiglione (“guide for driver of post-coach”), from posta (“post”).

entries.meaning: A rider mounted on the near (left) leading horse who guides the team pulling a carriage.
examples: To play the postilion is not an easy thing. It is a trade by itself—half a gunner's and half a groom's. It has to do with horses—that is bad enough ; but also it involves some knowledge of the road.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A post-boy, a messenger boy, a swift letter carrier.
